header.title: Dagon Rising: The Litany of Dagon

central_thesis: This text presents a synthesis of Lovecraftian cosmic horror with Qabalistic and Thelemic magical principles to construct a practical system for invoking Dagon, re-establishing his primordial potency, and facilitating the manifestation of associated 'Mighty Ones' or 'chaos dragons' into conscious experience, thereby unlocking deeper levels of human subconsciousness and traversing spiritual thresholds.

structure_content.chapter_title: 1. Dagon in the writing of H. P. Lovecraft
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines Dagon's appearances in H. P. Lovecraft's stories, 'Dagon' (1917) and 'The Shadow over Innsmouth' (1931), where he is linked to the Deep Ones and the Esoteric Order of Dagon. It also discusses August Derleth's rationalization of Dagon's role within the Cthulhu Mythos, positioning him as subservient to Cthulhu, and highlights scholarly interpretations of Lovecraft's use of Dagon, particularly the connection to 'Babylonish abominations' mentioned by Zadok Allen.

This chapter provides the core ritual text, 'The Litany of Dagon,' comprising 27 lines, and offers a detailed Qabalistic commentary. The litany is designed to reverse Dagon's biblical 'fallen' state (1 Samuel 5) and re-establish his worship. Gematria is extensively used to link phrases and concepts, such as the 'seven periods of time' of suppression, the 'Year of Jubilee' (Aeon of Dagon's Rising), and the 'Gate of the Fishes' (ShOR HDGIM) as an entry to the Apsu. It emphasizes the 'Great Sacrifice to Dagon' and the manifestation of 'Mighty Ones from Eternity'.

This chapter delves into the historical and archaeological origins of Dagon, debunking the common misconception of him as a fish-god. It traces his roots as a West Semitic god of grain ('corn, grain') and earth (DGN), head of a pantheon at Ebla (Dagan), worshipped by Amorites, Sumerians, and Philistines. The chapter highlights his association with Enlil and his later identification with fertility, rain, thunder (Baal as 'son of Dagon'), and ultimately, Zeus Ploughman (Ζευσ Αροτριοσ). The misrepresentation as a merman is attributed to later Hellenic influences and denigration in Jewish scriptures.

This chapter formulates a magical image for Dagon based on Qabalistic and Thelemic Tarot correspondences. It identifies Dagon (DGVN=63, reducing to 9) with Atu IX, The Hermit, in the Thoth Tarot. The Hermit's symbolism of fertility (Virgo), the guide through lower regions (Psychopompos), and the Abyss is linked to Dagon. The chapter also connects Dagon's 'head' or 'skull' (GLGLTh) to the 'dragon brain' (cerebellum) as a microcosmic threshold to primordial spaces, and details a talismanic design derived from Dagon's gematria plotted on the Kamea of Mercury.

key_concepts.definition: An ancient West Semitic deity, initially a god of grain and earth, later associated with fertility, rain, and thunder. Historically misidentified as a fish-god. In Lovecraft's lore, he is the progenitor of the Deep Ones. In this system, he is a Great Old One whose primordial potency is to be magically re-established.

H. P. Lovecraft's fictional universe of cosmic horror, including entities like Dagon and Cthulhu, which is integrated into the magical framework, drawing parallels between its lore and traditional occult concepts.

A system of Jewish mysticism that assigns numerical values to Hebrew letters and words. It is used here as a primary tool for interpreting biblical texts, finding hidden correspondences, constructing the Litany of Dagon, and deriving Dagon's magical image and attributes.

A ritual invocation text, presented in the book, meticulously constructed from biblical references (e.g., 1 Samuel 5) and Qabalistic gematria. Its purpose is to perform an operative magical act of 're-establishing' Dagon's fallen state and invoking his manifestation.
Amphibious, frog-like, fish creatures from H. P. Lovecraft's stories, depicted as servants of Cthulhu and offspring or associates of Dagon, residing in the depths of the ocean.

A biblical concept (every 50th year) signifying a time of release, liberation, and the sounding of trumpets. Through gematria, it is identified with the value 803 and correlated with the 'Aeon of Dagon's Rising' within the magical system, marking a cosmic period of transition.

Historically, one of the northern gates of Jerusalem. In this esoteric context, it is reinterpreted as a symbolic entrance to the Apsu (the watery abyss of Sumero-Babylonian cosmology) and a metaphor for the manifestation point of Dagon and related entities.

An occult representation of Dagon, not based on historical statues, but formulated through Qabalistic analysis. Dagon's Hebrew name (DGVN) having a value of 63 (reduces to 9) links him to Atu IX (The Hermit) in the Thoth Tarot, embodying fertility, the Abyss, Mercury (Logos/Psychopompos), and the 'dragon brain' (cerebellum).

The numerical value (583) derived from the gematria of 'all who enter the house of Dagon'. This number is interpreted as a key identifier, signifying knowledge of the eleven chaos dragons (from Babylonian Creation Epic) and connecting to Nuit's declaration 'My number is 11' from Liber Al.

practical_system.description: The practical system centers on the invocation of Dagon through 'The Litany of Dagon,' a ritual text constructed from biblical allusions and Qabalistic gematria. The ritual aims to reverse Dagon's biblical 'fallen' state, re-establishing his sovereignty and releasing associated primal entities (chaos dragons/Deep Ones). It involves specific ritual actions like adoration, chanting, and a 'Great Sacrifice.' Further operative components include the contemplation and use of a talismanic design derived from Dagon's Qabalistic values mapped onto the Kamea of Mercury, and its integration with the Thoth Tarot's Atu IX (The Hermit), which represents Dagon's magical image, linking him to fertility, the Abyss, and the 'dragon brain' (cerebellum) as a threshold to primordial consciousness.
tools: Talismanic design based on Dagon's gematria and the Kamea of Mercury
Atu IX (The Hermit) of the Thoth Tarot
rituals: Leaping across the threshold (symbolic or physical)

relevant_quotes.text: In his house at R'lyeh dead Cthulhu waits dreaming.

Wrath o'Jehovy - I was a mighty little critter, but I heerd what I heerd an' seen what I seen - Dagon an' Ashtoreth - Belial an' Beelzebub - Golden Caff an' the idols o' Canaan an' the Philistines - Babylonish abominations - Mene, mene tekel, upharsin...
Dagon will come again, as will mighty sorceries for the mighty beasts of the deep have been unleashed, and they have gone about their pathway of destruction...

The highest symbolism of this card is, therefore, Fertility in its most exalted sense, and this is reflected in the attribu-tion of the card to the sign of Virgo, which is another aspect of the same quality. Virgo is an earthy sign, and is referred especially to Corn, so that the background of the card is a field of wheat.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to modern occultism, particularly practitioners of Chaos Magic, Thelema, and Lovecraftian magic. It exemplifies a sophisticated methodology for syncretizing fictional mythologies (Cthulhu Mythos) with established esoteric systems (Qabalah, Tarot, Hermeticism) and historical religious data to forge a new, operative magical system. It serves as a practical demonstration of myth-making, sigilization through gematria, and the active engagement with and re-interpretation of cultural narratives within a magical context, providing a framework for accessing and manipulating specific energetic currents.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists primarily of experienced occultists, Thelemites, Chaos magicians, and practitioners of Lovecraftian magic. Familiarity with Qabalah (including Gematria), Tarot (specifically Crowley's Thoth deck), and Western Esotericism is presumed. Its advanced syncretic nature and reliance on pre-existing esoteric knowledge make it unsuitable for beginners, requiring a solid foundation in magical theory and practice to be understood and applied effectively.
